#Text=THE MAN ALONE
#Text=INTRODUCTION .
#Text=ON February the First 1887 , the Lady Vain was lost by collision with a derelict when about the latitude 1 degree S. and longitude 107 degrees W.

#Text=On January the Fifth , 1888 -- that is eleven months and four days after -- my uncle , Edward Prendick , a private gentleman , who certainly went aboard the Lady Vain at Callao , and who had been considered drowned , was picked up in latitude 5 degrees 3 ' S. and longitude 101 degrees W. in a small open boat of which the name was illegible , but which is supposed to have belonged to the missing schooner Ipecacuanha .
#Text=He gave such a strange account of himself that he was supposed demented .
#Text=Subsequently he alleged that his mind was a blank from the moment of his escape from the Lady Vain .
#Text=His case was discussed among psychologists at the time as a curious instance of the lapse of memory consequent upon physical and mental stress .
#Text=The following narrative was found among his papers by the undersigned , his nephew and heir , but unaccompanied by any definite request for publication .
#Text=The only island known to exist in the region in which my uncle was picked up is Noble 's Isle , a small volcanic islet and uninhabited .
#Text=It was visited in 1891 by H. M. S. Scorpion .
#Text=A party of sailors then landed , but found nothing living thereon except certain curious white moths , some hogs and rabbits , and some rather peculiar rats .
#Text=So that this narrative is without confirmation in its most essential particular .
#Text=With that understood , there seems no harm in putting this strange story before the public in accordance , as I believe , with my uncle 's intentions .
#Text=There is at least this much in its behalf :
#Text=my uncle passed out of human knowledge about latitude 5 degrees S. and longitude 105 degrees E. , and reappeared in the same part of the ocean after a space of eleven months .
#Text=In some way he must have lived during the interval .

#Text=And it seems that a schooner called the Ipecacuanha with a drunken captain , John Davies , did start from Africa with a puma and certain other animals aboard in January , 1887 , that the vessel was well known at several ports in the South Pacific , and that it finally disappeared from those seas ( with a considerable amount of copra aboard ) , sailing to its unknown fate from Bayna in December , 1887 , a date that tallies entirely with my uncle 's story .
#Text=CHARLES EDWARD PRENDICK .
#Text=( The Story written by Edward Prendick . )
#Text=I. IN THE DINGEY OF THE " LADY VAIN . "
#Text=I DO not propose to add anything to what has already been written concerning the loss of the " Lady Vain . "
#Text=As everyone knows , she collided with a derelict when ten days out from Callao .

#Text=The longboat , with seven of the crew , was picked up eighteen days after by H. M. gunboat " Myrtle , " and the story of their terrible privations has become quite as well known as the far more horrible " Medusa " case .
#Text=But I have to add to the published story of the " Lady Vain " another , possibly as horrible and far stranger .
#Text=It has hitherto been supposed that the four men who were in the dingey perished , but this is incorrect .
#Text=I have the best of evidence for this assertion : I was one of the four men .
#Text=But in the first place I must state that there never were four men in the dingey , -- the number was three .
#Text=Constans , who was " seen by the captain to jump into the gig , " { 1 }
#Text=luckily for us and unluckily for himself did not reach us .

#Text=He came down out of the tangle of ropes under the stays of the smashed bowsprit , some small rope caught his heel as he let go , and he hung for a moment head downward , and then fell and struck a block or spar floating in the water .
#Text=We pulled towards him , but he never came up .
#Text={ 1 }
#Text=Daily News , March 17 , 1887 .

#Text=I say luckily for us he did not reach us , and I might almost say luckily for himself ; for we had only a small beaker of water and some soddened ship 's biscuits with us , so sudden had been the alarm , so unprepared the ship for any disaster .
#Text=We thought the people on the launch would be better provisioned ( though it seems they were not ) , and we tried to hail them .
#Text=They could not have heard us , and the next morning when the drizzle cleared , -- which was not until past midday , --
#Text=we could see nothing of them .
#Text=We could not stand up to look about us , because of the pitching of the boat .
#Text=The two other men who had escaped so far with me were a man named Helmar , a passenger like myself , and a seaman whose name I do n't know , -- a short sturdy man , with a stammer .
